awd_titl_txt: Unveiling the Formation and Evolution of Neutron Star and Black Hole Binaries
awd_abstract_narration:
Margaret Lazzarini is awarded an NSF Astronomy and Astrophysics Fellowship to carry out a program of research and education at the California Institute of Technology.  Using observations at infrared, optical, ultraviolet, and X-ray wavelengths, Lazzarini will study properties of high-mass X-ray binary (HMXB) systems containing a star and a massive compact object (CO) such as a neutron star or a black hole.  Results from this project will allow astronomers to better understand binary stellar evolution and how HMXBs yield binary COs which can undergo mergers to produce gravitational waves.   Lazzarini will also conduct a weekly after school enrichment program which will provide astronomy research experiences to high school students from underserved communities.

Lazzarini will use photometry, time-resolved spectroscopy, and computational binary evolution modeling to place precise constraints on the allowed common envelope efficiency and supernova kick magnitudes of over 200 HMXBs in three nearby galaxies: M31, M33, and the Small Magellanic Cloud.  By constraining these two parameters in a large sample of HMXBs in a wide range of galactic environments, this project will greatly improve formation models of CO mergers via isolated binary stellar evolution and enable precise estimates of the rates of merger events producing GWs.  This project advances the goals of the NSF Windows on the Universe Big Idea.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This NSF Astronomy & Astrophysics Postdoctoral Fellowship (AAPF) supported research on the complex of massive binary stellar evolution. 


After the primary star in a massive stellar binary becomes a compact object (CO), the system can enter the X-ray binary phase, when the system becomes bright at X-ray wavelengths due to accretion from the companion star onto the CO. When the companion star in the system is a massive star (> 8 times the mass of the sun), the system is called a high mass X-ray binary (HMXB). 

I completed a detailed multi-wavelength characterization of the high mass X-ray binary population in the nearby spiral galaxy M33, with the aim of understanding how galaxy-wide properties affect the resulting demographics of the HMXB population. In parallel with this observational work, this AAPF fellowship supported theoretical work using binary population synthesis models to simulate the HMXB populations of M33 so that these theoretical binaries could be compared to their observed counterparts.


The first step to studying the HMXB population of the galaxy M33 was to measure the galaxy’s history of star formation. I measured the spatially resolved recent star formation history of M33 and published maps detailing the rate at which new stars have been formed at different locations in the galaxy over the last 600 million years. These maps are critical for studying HMXBs since they were used to determine the age distribution and production rate of high mass X-ray binaries in M33.


I then used optical/ultraviolet imaging from the Hubble Space Telescope in combination with X-ray observations from the Chandra X-ray observatory to identify and characterize the population of HMXBs in M33. The major results of this study include 1. finding that the population of HMXBs in M33 is dominated by Be X-ray binaries, systems where a compact object accretes material from a rapidly rotating massive (O or B type) main sequence star, 2. that the production rate of HMXBs in M33 peaked between 0 and 10 million years ago and also between 40 and 50 million years ago, suggesting two distinct formation channels for HMXBs in this galaxy, and 3. there is an observed preference for accreting black holes to be in binaries with giant/supergiant companion stars and a preference for neutron stars to be in binaries with main sequence stars.


This award also allowed me to compare observed HMXB populations with theoretical populations created with binary population synthesis models. This work is still underway and is important for using observations to constrain models of massive binary stellar evolution, which are used to predict compact object merger rates.


I was awarded 7 half nights of observation time using the DEIMOS spectrograph on the 10 meter Keck II telescope in Hawaii as an NSF postdoctoral fellow. I obtained optical spectra for ~100 HMXB companion star candidates. These observations have allowed me to eliminate contaminating sources in my HMXB sample and further characterize HMXB systems in M33, which is still underway.


Lastly, this NSF award allowed me to further my goals of making high quality STEM educational enrichment available to students across Los Angeles. While supported by this NSF award, I mentored 6 high school students from Los Angeles area public high schools in summer astrophysics research projects at Caltech. I co-led an after school program at a Los Angeles public high school for students interested in STEM during the 2021-2022 school year. In the 2022-2023 school year I led 9 classroom visits at a Los Angeles public high school, where I presented on career paths in physics and astronomy and led students in citizen science projects. I also led 2 public stargazing nights attended by over 50 students, teachers, families at a Los Angeles public high school.
